ability: the quality of being able to perform; a quality that permits or facilitates achievement or accomplishment
able: have the skills and qualifications to do things well
about: with regard to; on account of; on the subject of; to affect
above: over; on top of; higher than
absent: not being in a specified place
absorb: suck or take up or in
abstract: a concept or idea not associated with any specific instance
absurd: inconsistent with reason or logic or common sense
access: the act of approaching or entering
accident: an unfortunate mishap; especially one causing damage or injury
account: a formal contractual relationship established to provide for regular banking or brokerage or business services
accuse: bring an accusation against; level a charge against
acid: any of various water-soluble compounds having a sour taste and capable of turning litmus red and reacting with a base to form a salt
acoustic: pertaining to the sense of hearing, the organs of hearing, or the science of sounds; auditory
acquire: come into the possession of something concrete or abstract
action: something done (usually as opposed to something said)
actual: presently existing in fact and not merely potential or possible
adapt: make fit for, or change to suit a new purpose
add: make an addition (to); join or combine or unite with others; increase the quality, quantity, size or scope of
addict: someone who is so ardently devoted to something that it resembles an addiction
address: the place where a person or organization can be found or communicated with
adjust: alter or regulate so as to achieve accuracy or conform to a standard
admit: declare to be true or admit the existence or reality or truth of
adult: a fully developed animal or person from maturity onward
advice: a proposal for an appropriate course of action
aerobic: living or occurring only in the presence of oxygen e.g. aerobic bacteria
afford: be able to spare or give up
agent: a representative who acts on behalf of other persons or organizations
agree: be in accord; be in agreement
ahead: in or to the front; in advance; onward
aim: the pointing of a weapon, as a gun, a dart, or an arrow, or object, in the line of direction with the object intended to be struck; the line of fire; the direction of anything, such as a spear, a blow, a discourse, a remark, towards a particular point or object, with a view to strike or affect it
air: a mixture of gases (especially oxygen) required for breathing; the stuff that the wind consists of
airport: an airfield equipped with control tower and hangars as well as accommodations for passengers and cargo
aisle: a long narrow passage (as in a cave or woods)
alarm: a device that signals the occurrence of some undesirable event
album: a book of blank pages with pockets or envelopes; for organizing photographs or stamp collections etc
alcohol: any of a series of volatile hydroxyl compounds that are made from hydrocarbons by distillation
alert: condition of heightened watchfulness or preparation for action
alien: a form of life assumed to exist outside the Earth or its atmosphere
all: quantifier; used with either mass or count nouns to indicate the whole number or amount of or every one of a class
alley: a narrow street with walls on both sides
almost: (of actions or states) slightly short of or not quite accomplished; all but
alpha: the 1st letter of the Greek alphabet
already: prior to a specified or implied time
alter: cause to change; make different; cause a transformation
always: at all times; all the time and on every occasion
amateur: someone who pursues a study or sport as a pastime
among: denotes a mingling or intermixing with distinct or separable objects
amount: a quantity obtained by the addition of a group of numbers
analyst: someone who is skilled at analyzing data
anchor: a mechanical device that prevents a vessel from moving
ancient: belonging to times long past especially of the historical period before the fall of the Western Roman Empire
anger: a strong emotion; a feeling that is oriented toward some real or supposed grievance
angle: the inclination of one line to another; measured in degrees or radians
animal: a living organism characterized by voluntary movement
ankle: a gliding joint between the leg and the foot
announce: to give public notice, especially for the first time; to make known
another: any of various alternatives; some other
answer: a response or reply; something said or done in reaction to a statement or question; a solution to a problem
antenna: an electrical device that sends or receives radio signals
antique: any piece of furniture or decorative object or the like produced in a former period and valuable because of its beauty or rarity
anxiety: a vague unpleasant emotion that is experienced in anticipation of some (usually ill-defined) misfortune
any: one or some or every or all without specification
apart: remote and separate physically or socially
apology: an expression of regret at having caused trouble for someone
appear: give a certain impression or have a certain outward aspect
apple: fruit with red or yellow or green skin and sweet to tart crisp whitish flesh
april: the month following March and preceding May
arch: a curved shape in the vertical plane that spans an opening
arctic: the regions to the north of the Arctic Circle centered on the North Pole
area: a measure of the extent of a surface; it is measured in square units
arena: the central area of an ancient Roman amphitheater where contests and spectacles were held; especially an area that was strewn with sand
arm: a human limb; technically the part of the superior limb between the shoulder and the elbow but commonly used to refer to the whole superior limb
armor: protective covering made of metal and used in combat
army: a permanent organization of the military land forces of a nation or state
arrange: put into a proper or systematic order
arrest: the act of apprehending (especially apprehending a criminal)
arrive: reach a destination; arrive by movement or progress
arrow: a projectile with a straight thin shaft and an arrowhead on one end and stabilizing vanes on the other; intended to be shot from a bow
artefact: a man-made object taken as a whole
artist: a person whose creative work shows sensitivity and imagination
artwork: photographs or other visual representations in a printed publication
aspect: a distinct feature or element in a problem
assault: close fighting during the culmination of a military attack
assist: the activity of contributing to the fulfillment of a need or furtherance of an effort or purpose
assume: take to be the case or to be true; accept without verification or proof
asthma: respiratory disorder characterized by wheezing; usually of allergic origin
athlete: a person trained to compete in sports
atom: (physics and chemistry) the smallest component of an element having the chemical properties of the element
attack: (military) an offensive against an enemy (using weapons)
attend: take charge of or deal with
attitude: the position of the body or way of carrying oneself
attract: direct toward itself or oneself by means of some psychological power or physical attributes
auction: the public sale of something to the highest bidder
audit: a methodical examination or review of a condition or situation
august: the month following July and preceding September
aunt: the sister of your father or mother; the wife of your uncle
author: n
the originator or creator of a work, especially of a literary composition
auto: a motor vehicle with four wheels; usually propelled by an internal combustion engine
autumn: the season when the leaves fall from the trees
average: a statistic describing the location of a distribution
avocado: a pear-shaped tropical fruit with green or blackish skin and rich yellowish pulp enclosing a single large seed
avoid: stay clear from; keep away from; keep out of the way of someone or something
awake: not in a state of sleep; completely conscious
aware: (sometimes followed by `of') having or showing knowledge or understanding or realization or perception
awesome: inspiring awe or admiration or wonder
awkward: hard to deal with; especially causing pain or embarrassment
axis: a straight line through a body or figure that satisfies certain conditions
baby: a very young child (birth to 1 year) who has not yet begun to walk or talk
bachelor: a man who has never been married
bacon: back and sides of a hog salted and dried or smoked; usually sliced thin and fried
badge: any feature that is regarded as a sign of status (a particular power or quality or rank)
bag: a flexible container with a single opening
balcony: a platform projecting from the wall of a building and surrounded by a balustrade or railing or parapet
ball: round object that is hit or thrown or kicked in games
bamboo: woody tropical grass having hollow woody stems; mature canes used for construction and furniture
banana: elongated crescent-shaped yellow fruit with soft sweet flesh
banner: long strip of cloth or paper used for decoration or advertising
bar: a room or establishment where alcoholic drinks are served over a counter
bargain: an agreement between parties (usually arrived at after discussion) fixing obligations of each
barrel: a tube through which a bullet travels when a gun is fired
base: installation from which a military force initiates operations
basic: (usually plural) a necessary commodity for which demand is constant
basket: a container that is usually woven and has handles
battle: a hostile meeting of opposing military forces in the course of a war
beach: an area of sand sloping down to the water of a sea or lake
bean: any of various edible seeds of plants of the family Leguminosae used for food
beauty: the qualities that give pleasure to the senses
because: by or for the cause that; on this account that; for the reason that
become: enter or assume a certain state or condition
beef: meat from an adult domestic bovine
begin: take the first step or steps in carrying out an action
behave: to conduct (oneself) well, or in a given way
behind: at the back of; positioned with something else in front of
believe: to accept as true, particularly without absolute certainty (i.e., as opposed to knowing)
belt: a band to tie or buckle around the body (usually at the waist)
bench: a long seat for more than one person
benefit: an advantage; help or aid from something
best: superlative form of good: most good
betray: to deliver into the hands of an enemy by treachery or fraud, in violation of trust; to give up treacherously or faithlessly
better: something superior in quality or condition or effect
between: in the position or interval that separates (two things), or intermediate in quantity or degree
beyond: farther along in space or time or degree
bicycle: a wheeled vehicle that has two wheels and is moved by foot pedals
bid: a formal proposal to buy at a specified price
bike: a wheeled vehicle that has two wheels
bind: make fast; tie or secure, with or as if with a rope
biology: the science that studies living organisms
bird: warm-blooded egg-laying vertebrates characterized by feathers and forelimbs modified as wings
birth: the process of childbearing; the beginning of life
bitter: the property of having a harsh unpleasant taste
black: the colour/color perceived in the absence of light, but also when no light is reflected, but rather absorbed
blade: the sharp cutting edge of a knife, chisel, or other tool, a razor blade/sword
blame: an accusation that someone are responsible for a lapse or misdeed
blast: a sudden very loud noise; an explosion (as of dynamite)
blood: the fluid (red in vertebrates) that is pumped through the body by the heart and contains plasma, blood cells, and platelets
blossom: a flower, especially one indicating that a fruit tree is fruiting; (collectively) a mass of such flowers
blue: of the color intermediate between green and violet; having a color similar to that of a clear unclouded sky
blur: to make indistinct or hazy, to obscure or dim
blush: sudden reddening of the face (as from embarrassment or guilt or shame or modesty)
board: a flat piece of material designed for a special purpose
boat: a small vessel for travel on water
body: the entire structure of an organism (an animal, plant, or human being)
boil: to heat to the point where it begins to turn into a gas
bomb: an explosive device fused to explode under specific conditions
bone: rigid connective tissue that makes up the skeleton of vertebrates
bonus: an extra or premium; any one-off gain
book: a written work or composition that has been published (printed on pages bound together)
boost: contribute to the progress or growth of
border: a line that indicates a boundary
boring: so lacking in interest as to cause mental weariness
boss: a person who exercises control over workers
box: a (usually rectangular) container; may have a lid
bracket: a category falling within certain defined limits
brain: that part of the central nervous system that includes all the higher nervous centers; enclosed within the skull; continuous with the spinal cord
brand: a name given to a product or service
brass: an alloy of copper and zinc
brave: possessing or displaying courage; able to face and deal with danger or fear without flinching
bread: food made from dough of flour or meal and usually raised with yeast or baking powder and then baked
brick: rectangular block of clay baked by the sun or in a kiln; used as a building or paving material
bridge: a structure that allows people or vehicles to cross an obstacle such as a river or canal or railway etc.
bright: emitting or reflecting light readily or in large amounts
bring: take something or somebody with oneself somewhere
brisk: full of liveliness and activity; characterized by quickness of motion or action
broccoli: plant with dense clusters of tight green flower buds
broken: physically and forcibly separated into pieces or cracked or split
bronze: an alloy of copper and tin and sometimes other elements; also any copper-base alloy containing other elements in place of tin
broom: a cleaning implement for sweeping; bundle of straws or twigs attached to a long handle
brother: a male with the same parents as someone else
brown: an orange color of low brightness and saturation
brush: an implement that has hairs or bristles firmly set into a handle
bubble: a hollow globule of gas (e.g., air or carbon dioxide)
buddy: a close friend who accompanies his buddies in their activities
budget: a summary of intended expenditures along with proposals for how to meet them
buffalo: large shaggy-haired brown bison of North American plains
build: make by combining materials and parts
bulb: electric lamp consisting of a transparent or translucent glass housing containing a wire filament (usually tungsten) that emits light when heated by electricity
bulk: the property resulting from being or relating to the greater in number of two parts; the main part
bullet: a projectile that is fired from a gun
bundle: a collection of things wrapped or boxed together
bunker: a fortification mostly or entirely below ground
burden: weight to be borne or conveyed
burger: a sandwich consisting of a fried cake of minced beef served on a bun, often with other ingredients
bus: a vehicle carrying many passengers; used for public transport
business: a commercial or industrial enterprise and the people who constitute it
busy: actively or fully engaged or occupied
butter: an edible emulsion of fat globules made by churning milk or cream; for cooking and table use
cabbage: any of various cultivars of the genus Brassica oleracea grown for their edible leaves or flowers
cabin: a small house built of wood; usually in a wooded area
cable: a conductor for transmitting electrical or optical signals or electric power
cactus: any succulent plant of the family Cactaceae native chiefly to arid regions of the New World and usually having spines
cage: an enclosure made or wire or metal bars in which birds or animals can be kept
cake: a rich, sweet dessert food, typically made of flour, sugar and eggs and baked in an oven, and often covered in icing
call: a loud utterance; often in protest or opposition
camera: equipment for taking photographs (usually consisting of a lightproof box with a lens at one end and light-sensitive film at the other)
camp: an outdoor place acting as temporary accommodation in tents or other temporary structures
can: airtight sealed metal container for food or drink or paint etc.
canal: long and narrow strip of water made for boats or for irrigation
cancel: postpone indefinitely or annul something that was scheduled
candy: a rich sweet made of flavored sugar
canoe: small and light boat; pointed at both ends; propelled with a paddle
canvas: a type of coarse cloth, woven from hemp, useful for making sails and tents or as a surface for paintings
canyon: a ravine formed by a river in an area with little rainfall
capable: (usually followed by `of') having capacity or ability
capital: wealth in the form of money or property owned by a person or business and human resources of economic value
captain: the person in command of a ship or other vessel
car: a motor vehicle with four wheels; usually propelled by an internal combustion engine
carbon: an abundant nonmetallic tetravalent element occurring in three allotropic forms: amorphous carbon and graphite and diamond; occurs in all organic compounds
card: one of a set of small pieces of stiff paper marked in various ways and used for playing games or for telling fortunes
cargo: goods carried by a large vehicle
carpet: floor covering consisting of a piece of thick heavy fabric
carry: move while supporting, either in a vehicle or in one's hands or on one's body
cart: a heavy open wagon usually having two wheels and drawn by an animal
cash: money in the form of bills or coins
cat: feline mammal usually having thick soft fur and no ability to roar: domestic cats; wildcats
catalog: a book or pamphlet containing an enumeration of things
catch: take hold of so as to seize or restrain or stop the motion of
category: a general concept that marks divisions or coordinations in a conceptual scheme
cattle: domesticated bovine animals as a group
cause: events that provide the generative force that is the origin of something
caution: the trait of being attentive to possible danger
cave: a geological formation consisting of an underground enclosure with access from the surface of the ground or from the sea
ceiling: the overhead upper surface of a covered space
celery: widely cultivated herb with aromatic leaf stalks that are eaten raw or cooked
cement: a building material that is a powder made of a mixture of calcined limestone and clay; used with water and sand or gravel to make concrete and mortar
cereal: grass whose starchy grains are used as food: wheat; rice; rye; oats; maize; buckwheat; millet
certain: having or feeling no doubt or uncertainty; confident and assured
chair: a seat for one person, with a support for the back
champion: someone who has won first place in a competition
change: a relational difference between states; especially between states before and after some event
chaos: a state of extreme confusion and disorder
chapter: a subdivision of a written work; usually numbered and titled
charge: an impetuous rush toward someone or something
chase: the act of pursuing in an effort to overtake or capture
cheap: relatively low in price or charging low prices
check: examine so as to determine accuracy, quality, or condition
cheese: a solid food prepared from the pressed curd of milk
cherry: any of numerous trees and shrubs producing a small fleshy round fruit with a single hard stone; many also produce a valuable hardwood
chest: the part of the human torso between the neck and the diaphragm or the corresponding part in other vertebrates
chicken: a domestic fowl bred for flesh or eggs; believed to have been developed from the red jungle fowl
chief: a person who is in charge
child: a young person of either sex
chimney: a vertical flue that provides a path through which smoke from a fire is carried away through the wall or roof of a building
choice: the person or thing chosen or selected
choose: pick out or select from a number of alternatives
chronic: being long-lasting and recurrent or characterized by long suffering
churn: stir (cream) vigorously in order to make butter
cigar: a roll of tobacco for smoking
cinnamon: spice from the dried aromatic bark of the Ceylon cinnamon tree; used as rolled strips or ground
circle: ellipse in which the two axes are of equal length; a plane curve generated by one point moving at a constant distance from a fixed point
citizen: a native or naturalized member of a state or other political community
city: a large and densely populated urban area; may include several independent administrative districts
civil: applying to ordinary citizens as contrasted with the military
claim: an assertion of a right (as to money or property); an assertion that something is true or factual
clap: strike with the flat of the hand; usually in a friendly way, as in encouragement or greeting
clarify: make clear and (more) comprehensible; make clear by removing impurities or solids, as by heating
claw: sharp curved horny process on the toe of a bird or some mammals or reptiles
clay: a very fine-grained soil that is plastic when moist but hard when fired
clean: free from dirt or impurities; or having clean habits
clerk: an employee who keeps records or accounts; a salesperson in a store
click: a short light metallic sound; depression of a button on a computer mouse
client: someone who pays for goods or services
cliff: a steep high face of rock
climb: go upward with gradual or continuous progress
clinic: a medical establishment run by a group of medical specialists
clip: a metal frame or container holding cartridges; can be inserted into an automatic gun
clock: a timepiece that shows the time of day
clog: become or cause to become obstructed
close: move so that an opening or passage is obstructed; make shut
cloth: artifact made by weaving or felting or knitting or crocheting natural or synthetic fibers
cloud: a visible mass of water or ice particles suspended at a considerable altitude
clown: a person who amuses others by ridiculous behavior
club: stout stick that is larger at one end
cousin: the child of your aunt or uncle
cover: a covering that serves to conceal or shelter something
coyote: small wolf native to western North America
crack: a blemish resulting from a break without complete separation of the parts
cradle: where something originated or was nurtured in its early existence
craft: the skilled practice of a practical occupation
cram: put something somewhere so that the space is completely filled
crane: lifts and moves heavy objects; lifting tackle is suspended from a pivoted boom that rotates around a vertical axis
crash: a serious accident (usually involving one or more vehicles)
crater: a bowl-shaped depression formed by the impact of a meteorite or bomb
crawl: a slow mode of locomotion on hands and knees or dragging the body
dash: a punctuation mark (-) used between parts of a compound word or between the syllables of a word when the word is divided at the end of a line of text
day: the time after sunrise and before sunset while it is light outside
deal: an agreement between parties (usually arrived at after discussion) fixing obligations of each
debate: a discussion in which reasons are advanced for and against some proposition or proposal
debris: the remains of something that has been destroyed or broken up
december: the last (12th) month of the year
decide: reach, make, or come to a decision about something
decline: a condition inferior to an earlier condition; a gradual falling off from a better state
decorate: make more attractive by adding ornament, colour, etc.
deer: distinguished from Bovidae by the male's having solid deciduous antlers
defense: (military) military action or resources protecting a country against potential enemies
defy: elude, especially in a baffling way
degree: a position on a scale of intensity or amount or quality
desk: a piece of furniture with a writing surface and usually drawers or other compartments
despair: a state in which all hope is lost or absent
destroy: to damage beyond use or repair
detail: a small part that can be considered separately from the whole
detect: discover or determine the existence, presence, or fact of
develop: make something new, such as a product or a mental or artistic creation
device: an instrumentality invented for a particular purpose
devote: give entirely to a specific person, activity, or cause
diagram: a drawing intended to explain how something works; a drawing showing the relation between the parts
dial: the circular graduated indicator on various measuring instruments
diamond: very hard native crystalline carbon valued as a gem
diary: a daily written record of (usually personal) experiences and observations
dice: a small cube with 1 to 6 spots on the six faces; a source of entropy used in gambling
diesel: a fuel derived from petroleum (or other oils) but heavier than gasoline/petrol
diet: the food and beverage a person or animal consumes
differ: not to have the same traits or characteristics; to be unalike or distinct
digital: property of representing values as discrete, usually binary, numbers rather than a continuous spectrum
dignity: the quality of being worthy of esteem or respect
dilemma: state of uncertainty or perplexity especially as requiring a choice between equally unfavorable options
dinner: the main meal of the day served in the evening or at midday
dinosaur: any of numerous extinct terrestrial reptiles of the Mesozoic era
direct: direct in spatial dimensions; proceeding without deviation or interruption; straight and short
dirt: a stain or spot (on clothes etc); any foreign substance that worsens appearance, filth
disease: an impairment of health or a condition of abnormal functioning
dish: a piece of dishware normally used as a container for holding or serving food
disorder: a condition in which things are not in their expected places
display: a visual representation of something; an electronic device that represents information in visual form
distance: size of the gap between two places
divert: send on a course or in a direction different from the planned or intended one
divide: to split or separate (something) into two or more parts
divorce: the legal dissolution of a marriage
dizzy: having or causing a whirling sensation; liable to falling
doctor: a licensed medical practitioner; a person who holds Ph.D. degree (or the equivalent) from an academic institution
document: writing that provides information (especially information of an official nature)
dog: a member of the genus Canis (probably descended from the common wolf) that has been domesticated by man since prehistoric times; occurs in many breeds
doll: a small replica of a person; used as a toy
dolphin: any of various small toothed whales with a beak-like snout; larger than porpoises
domain: a field or sphere of activity, influence or expertise
donate: give to a charity or good cause
donkey: domestic beast of burden descended from the African wild ass; patient but stubborn
donor: person who makes a gift of property
door: a swinging or sliding barrier that will close the entrance to a room or building or vehicle
dose: a measured portion of medicine taken at any one time
double: a quantity that is twice as great as another
draft: a preliminary sketch of a design or picture
dragon: a legendary serpentine or reptilian creature
drama: a composition, normally in prose, telling a story and intended for performance by actors on a stage
draw: make a mark or lines on a surface
dream: a series of mental images and emotions occurring during sleep; imaginative thoughts indulged in while awake
dress: a one-piece garment for a woman; has skirt and bodice
drift: the gradual departure from an intended course due to external influences (as a ship or plane)
drill: a tool with a sharp point and cutting edges for making holes in hard materials (usually by rotating)
drink: a single serving of a beverage
drip: to fall one drop at a time
drop: a small indefinite quantity (especially of a liquid)
drum: a musical percussion instrument; usually consists of a hollow cylinder with a membrane stretched across each end
dry: free from liquid or moisture; lacking natural or normal moisture or depleted of water; or no longer wet
duck: small wild or domesticated web-footed broad-billed swimming bird usually having a depressed body and short legs
dumb: slow to learn or understand; lacking intellectual acuity; lacking the power of human speech
dune: a ridge of sand created by the wind; found in deserts or near lakes and oceans
eyebrow: the arch of hair above each eye
fabric: artifact made by weaving or felting or knitting or crocheting natural or synthetic fibers
face: the front of the human head from the forehead to the chin and ear to ear
faculty: the body of teachers and administrators at a school
faint: a spontaneous loss of consciousness caused by insufficient blood to the brain
faith: the process of forming or understanding abstractions, ideas, or beliefs, without empirical evidence, experience or observation
fall: a sudden drop from an upright position
false: not in accordance with the fact or reality or actuality; not true
fame: the state or quality of being widely honored and acclaimed
family: a group of people who are closely related to one another (by blood, marriage or adoption); kin; a set of parents and their children; an immediate family
fan: a device for creating a current of air by movement of a surface or surfaces
fancy: a kind of imagination more casual and superficial than true imagination
farm: a place where agricultural and similar activities take place, especially the growing of crops or the raising of livestock
fashion: a current (constantly changing) trend, favored for frivolous rather than practical, logical, or intellectual reasons
fat: a soft greasy substance occurring in organic tissue and consisting of a mixture of lipids (mostly triglycerides)
fatal: having momentous consequences; of decisive importance
father: a male parent (also used as a term of address to your father)
fatigue: temporary loss of strength and energy resulting from hard physical or mental work
fault: responsibility for a bad situation or event
feature: a prominent attribute or aspect of something
february: the month following January and preceding March
follow: to travel behind, go after, come after
food: any substance that can be metabolized by an animal to give energy and build tissue
foot: the part of the leg of a human being below the ankle joint
forest: land that is covered with trees and shrubs
forget: to lose remembrance of. dismiss from the mind; stop remembering
fork: cutlery used for serving and eating food
fortune: a large amount of wealth or prosperity
glove: handwear: covers the hand and wrist
glow: the phenomenon of light emission by a body as its temperature is raised
glue: cement consisting of a sticky substance that is used as an adhesive
goat: any of numerous agile ruminants similar to sheep but having a beard and straight horns
gold: a soft yellow malleable ductile (trivalent and univalent) metallic element; occurs mainly as nuggets in rocks and alluvial deposits; does not react with most chemicals but is attacked by chlorine and aqua regia
good: having desirable or positive qualities; moral excellence or admirableness
goose: web-footed long-necked typically gregarious migratory aquatic birds usually larger and less aquatic than ducks
gorilla: largest anthropoid ape; terrestrial and vegetarian; of forests of central west Africa
gospel: the four books in the New Testament (Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John) that tell the story of Christ's life and teachings
gossip: a report (often malicious) about the behavior of other people
govern: bring into conformity with rules or principles or usage; impose regulations
gown: a woman's dress, usually with a close-fitting bodice and a long flared skirt, often worn on formal occasions
grab: take hold of so as to seize or restrain or stop the motion of
grace: elegance and beauty of movement or expression
grain: a relatively small granular particle of a substance
grape: any of various juicy fruit of the genus Vitis with green or purple skins; grow in clusters
grass: narrow-leaved green herbage: grown as lawns; used as pasture for grazing animals; cut and dried as hay
gravity: (physics) the force of attraction between all masses in the universe; especially the attraction of the earth's mass for bodies near its surface
green: green color or pigment; resembling the color of growing grass
grid: a pattern of regularly spaced horizontal and vertical lines
grief: intense sorrow caused by loss of a loved one (especially by death)
grit: a collection of hard small materials, such as dirt, ground stone, debris from sandblasting or other such grinding, or swarf from metalworking
grocery: (usually plural) retail foodstuffs and other household supplies
group: any number of entities (members) considered as a unit
grow: become larger, greater, or bigger; expand or gain
grunt: the short low gruff noise of the kind made by hogs
guard: a person who protects by keeping watch over something or someone
guess: an estimate based on little or no information
guide: someone who shows the way by leading or advising
guilt: remorse caused by feeling responsible for some offense
guitar: a stringed instrument usually having six strings; played by strumming or plucking
gun: a weapon that discharges a missile at high velocity (especially from a metal tube or barrel)
gym: athletic facility equipped for sports or physical training
habit: an established custom; a pattern of behavior
hair: a covering for the body (or parts of it) consisting of a dense growth of threadlike structures (as on the human head); helps to prevent heat loss
half: one of two equal parts of a divisible whole
hammer: a hand tool with a heavy rigid head and a handle; used to deliver an impulsive force by striking
hamster: short-tailed Old World burrowing rodent with large cheek pouches
hand: the part of the fore limb below the forearm or wrist in a human, and the corresponding part in many other animals
happy: enjoying or showing or marked by joy or pleasure
harbor: a sheltered port where ships can take on or discharge cargo
hard: having a severe property; presenting difficulty; resistant to pressure, strong
harsh: unpleasantly stern; disagreeable to the senses; unkind or cruel or uncivil; severe
harvest: the yield from plants in a single growing season
hat: a covering for the head, often in the approximate form of a cone or a cylinder closed at its top end, and sometimes having a brim and other decoration
hawk: diurnal bird of prey typically having short rounded wings and a long tail
hazard: a source of danger; a possibility of incurring loss or misfortune
head: n
the upper part of the human body or the front part of the body in animals; contains the face and brains
health: the state of being free from physical or psychological disease, illness, or malfunction; wellness
heart: the hollow muscular organ located behind the sternum and between the lungs; its rhythmic contractions move the blood through the body
heavy: of comparatively great physical weight or density
hedgehog: relatively large rodents with sharp erectile bristles mingled with the fur
height: the vertical dimension of extension; distance from the base of something to the top
helmet: armor plate that protects the head
hero: somebody who possesses great bravery and carries out extraordinary or noble deeds
hidden: not accessible to view; designed to elude detection
high: a lofty level or position or degree
hill: a local and well-defined elevation of the land
hint: an indirect suggestion; a slight indication
hip: either side of the body below the waist and above the thigh
hire: engage for service under a term of contract
hobby: an activity that one enjoys doing in one's spare time
hockey: a game played on an ice rink by two opposing teams of six skaters each who try to knock a flat round puck into the opponents' goal with angled sticks
jump: to propel oneself rapidly upward, downward and/or in any horizontal direction such that momentum causes the body to become airborne
jungle: a large, undeveloped, humid forest, especially in a tropical region, that is home to many wild plants and animals
junior: younger; lower in rank; shorter in length of tenure or service
junk: the remains of something that has been destroyed or broken up
just: fair to all parties as dictated by reason and conscience
kangaroo: a herbivorous leaping marsupials of Australia and New Guinea having large powerful hind legs and a long thick tail
key: device able to unlock something to get to or to what is within
kick: delivering a blow with the foot
kidney: either of two bean-shaped excretory organs that filter wastes (especially urea) from the blood and excrete them and water in urine
lift: the event of something being raised upward
light: (physics) electromagnetic radiation that can produce a visual sensation
limb: one of the jointed appendages of an animal used for locomotion or grasping: arm; leg; wing; flipper
limit: as far as something can go
link: the means of connection between things linked in series; a fastener that serves to join or connect
lion: large gregarious predatory feline of Africa and India having a tawny coat with a shaggy mane in the male
liquid: existing as or having characteristics of a liquid; especially tending to flow
list: a compilation or enumeration of a set of possible items; the compilation or enumeration itself
little: limited or below average in number or quantity or magnitude or extent
lizard: relatively long-bodied reptile with usually two pairs of legs and a tapering tail
load: weight to be borne or conveyed
loan: the temporary provision of money (usually at interest)
lobster: black or brown (when alive) or red (when cooked) colored crustacean known for its meat
local: of or belonging to or characteristic of a particular locality or neighborhood
lock: a fastener fitted to a door or drawer to keep it firmly closed
mammal: any warm-blooded vertebrate having the skin more or less covered with hair; young are born alive except for the small subclass of monotremes and nourished with milk
master: someone who has control over something or someone
match: lighter consisting of a thin piece of wood or cardboard tipped with combustible chemical; ignites with friction
material: the tangible substance that goes into the makeup of a physical object
math: a science (or group of related sciences) dealing with the logic of quantity and shape and arrangement
matrix: (mathematics) a rectangular array of quantities or expressions set out by rows and columns; treated as a single element and manipulated according to rules
maze: complex system of paths or tunnels in which it is easy to get lost
meadow: a field where grass or alfalfa are grown to be made into hay
mean: an average of n numbers computed by adding some function of the numbers and dividing by some function of n
measure: the act or process of assigning numbers to phenomena according to a rule
meat: the flesh of animals (including fishes and birds and snails) used as food
mechanic: a craftsman skilled in operating machine tools
medal: an award for winning a championship or commemorating some other event
media: a means or instrumentality for storing or communicating information
melody: tune; sequence of notes that makes up a musical phrase
melt: the process whereby heat changes something from a solid to a liquid
member: one of the persons who compose a social group (especially individuals who have joined and participate in a group organization)
memory: a record of a thing or an event stored and available for later use
mention: a speaking or notice of anything, usually in a brief or cursory manner, used especially in the phrase make mention of
menu: a list of dishes available at a restaurant
mercy: leniency and compassion shown toward offenders by a person or agency charged with administering justice
merry: full of or showing high-spirited merriment
mesh: an open fabric of string or rope or wire woven together at regular intervals
message: a communication (usually brief) that is written or spoken or signaled
metal: any of several chemical elements that are usually shiny solids that conduct heat or electricity and can be formed into sheets etc.
method: a way of doing something, especially a systematic way; implies an orderly logical arrangement (usually in steps)
middle: an area that is approximately central within some larger region
midnight: 12 o'clock at night; the middle of the night
milk: a white nutritious liquid secreted by mammals and used as food by human beings
million: the number that is represented as a one followed by 6 zeros
mimic: imitate (a person or manner), especially for satirical effect
mind: that which is responsible for one's thoughts and feelings; the seat of the faculty of reason
minute: a unit of time equal to 60 seconds or 1/60th of an hour
miracle: a marvellous event manifesting a supernatural act of a divine agent
mirror: polished surface that forms images by reflecting light
misery: a state of ill-being due to affliction or misfortune
miss: a failure to hit (or meet or find etc)
mistake: a wrong action attributable to bad judgment or ignorance or inattention
mix: a commercially prepared mixture of dry ingredients
mixed: consisting of an assortment of different kinds
mixture: a collection containing a variety of sorts of things
model: any copy, or resemblance, more or less exact
modify: cause to change; make different; cause a transformation
monitor: a device that detects and informs on the presence, quantity, etc., of something
monkey: any of various long-tailed primates (excluding the prosimians)
monster: an imaginary creature usually having various human and animal parts
month: one of the twelve divisions of the calendar year; a time unit of approximately 30 days
moon: the natural satellite of the Earth
moral: concerned with principles of right and wrong or conforming to standards of behavior and character based on those principles
more: (comparative of `much' used with mass nouns) a quantifier meaning greater in size or amount or extent or degree
morning: the time period between dawn and noon
mosquito: two-winged insect whose female has a long proboscis to pierce the skin and suck the blood of humans and animals
mother: a woman who has given birth to a child (also used as a term of address to your mother)
motor: machine that converts other forms of energy into mechanical energy and so imparts motion
mountain: a land mass that projects well above its surroundings; higher than a hill
mouse: any of numerous small rodents typically resembling diminutive rats having pointed snouts and small ears on elongated bodies with slender usually hairless tails
move: to change place or posture; to go, in any manner, from one place or position to another
movie: a form of entertainment that enacts a story by sound and a sequence of images giving the illusion of continuous movement
muffin: a sweet quick bread baked in a cup-shaped pan
mule: hybrid offspring of a male donkey and a female horse; usually sterile
muscle: one of the contractile organs of the body
museum: a depository for collecting and displaying objects having scientific or historical or artistic value
mushroom: any of various fleshy fungi of the subdivision Basidiomycota consisting of a cap at the end of a stem arising from an underground mycelium
music: an artistic form of auditory communication incorporating instrumental or vocal tones in a structured and continuous manner
mutual: common to or shared by two or more parties
myself: me, as direct or indirect object the speaker as the object of a verb or preposition, when the speaker is also the subject
mystery: something that baffles understanding and cannot be explained
myth: a traditional story accepted as history; serves to explain the world view of a people
naive: marked by or showing unaffected simplicity and lack of guile or worldly experience
name: n
a language unit by which a person or thing is known
napkin: a small piece of table linen that is used to wipe the mouth and to cover the lap in order to protect clothing
nation: a historically constituted, stable community of people, formed on the basis of a common language, territory, economic life, ethnicity and/or psychological make-up manifested in a common culture
nature: the natural physical world including plants and animals and landscapes etc.
near: not far distant in time or space or degree or circumstances
neck: the part of an organism (human or animal) that connects the head to the rest of the body
need: anything that is necessary but lacking
neither: not either; not one or the other
nephew: a son of your brother or sister
orchard: garden consisting of a small cultivated wood without undergrowth
oven: kitchen appliance used for baking or roasting
oxygen: a nonmetallic bivalent element that is normally a colorless odorless tasteless nonflammable diatomic gas; constitutes 21 percent of the atmosphere by volume; the most abundant element in the earth's crust
oyster: marine mollusks having a rough irregular shell; found on the sea bed mostly in coastal waters
ozone: a colorless gas (O3) soluble in alkalis and cold water; a strong oxidizing agent; can be produced by electric discharge in oxygen or by the action of ultraviolet radiation on oxygen in the stratosphere (where it acts as a screen for ultraviolet radiation)
pact: a written agreement between two states or sovereigns
paddle: a two-handed, single-bladed oar used to propel a canoe or a small boat
page: one side of a paper leaf on which one has written or printed
pair: a set of two similar things considered as a unit
palm: the inner surface of the hand from the wrist to the base of the fingers
panda: large black-and-white herbivorous mammal of bamboo forests of China and Tibet; in some classifications considered a member of the bear family or of a separate family Ailuropodidae
panel: sheet that forms a distinct (usually flat and rectangular) section or component of something
panic: an overwhelming feeling of fear and anxiety
panther: a big cat with black fur; most especially, the black-coated leopard of India
paper: A sheet material used for writing on or printing on made of cellulose pulp derived mainly from wood or rags or certain grasses
parade: a ceremonial procession including people marching
parent: one of the two persons from whom one is immediately biologically descended; a mother or father
park: an area of land set aside for environment preservation or recreation
parrot: usually brightly colored zygodactyl tropical birds with short hooked beaks and the ability to mimic sounds
party: an occasion on which people can assemble for social interaction and entertainment; an organization to gain political power
pass: the location in a range of mountains of a geological formation that is lower than the surrounding peaks
patch: a piece of cloth used as decoration or to mend or cover a hole
pipe: a tube with a small bowl at one end; used for smoking tobacco
pistol: a firearm that is held and fired with one hand
pitch: the property of sound that varies with variation in the frequency of vibration
pizza: Italian open pie made of thin bread dough spread with a spiced mixture of e.g. tomato sauce and cheese
planet: (astronomy) any of the nine large celestial bodies in the solar system that revolve around the sun and shine by reflected light; Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune, and Pluto in order of their proximity to the sun; viewed from the constellation Hercules, all the planets rotate around the sun in a counterclockwise direction
plastic: generic name for certain synthetic or semisynthetic materials that can be molded or extruded into objects or films or filaments or used for making e.g. coatings and adhesives
plate: dish on which food is served or from which food is eaten
play: activity by children that is guided more by imagination than by fixed rules
pledge: a binding commitment to do or give or refrain from something
pluck: the act of pulling and releasing a taut cord
plug: blockage consisting of an object designed to fill a hole tightly
poem: a composition written in metrical feet forming rhythmical lines
poet: a writer of poems (the term is usually reserved for writers of good poetry)
point: a geometric element that has position but no extension
polar: located at or near or coming from the earth's poles
pole: a long (usually round) rod of wood or metal or plastic
police: a civil force granted the legal authority for law enforcement and maintaining public order
pony: any of various breeds of small gentle horses usually less than five feet high at the shoulder
pool: an excavation that is (usually) filled with water
popular: regarded with great favor, approval, or affection especially by the general public
position: the particular portion of space occupied by something
post: any particular collection of letters or packages that is delivered
potato: an edible tuber native to South America; a staple food of Ireland
pottery: ceramic ware made from clay and baked in a kiln
poverty: the state of having little or no money and few or no material possessions
powder: a solid substance in the form of tiny loose particles; a solid that has been pulverized
power: a quality that can make things happen
praise: offering words of homage as an act of worship
predict: make a prediction about; tell in advance
prepare: make ready or suitable or equip in advance for a particular purpose or for some use, event, etc
pretty: pleasing by delicacy or grace; not imposing
prevent: keep from happening or arising; make impossible
price: the amount of money needed to purchase something
pride: a feeling of self-respect and personal worth
primary: of first rank or importance or value; direct and immediate rather than secondary
prison: a correctional institution where persons are confined while on trial or for punishment
private: belonging to, concerning, or accessible only to an individual person or a specific group
prize: something given as a token of victory
problem: a state of difficulty that needs to be resolved
process: a particular course of action intended to achieve a result
produce: create or manufacture a man-made product
profit: the excess of revenues over outlays in a given period of time (including depreciation and other non-cash expenses)
project: s planned endeavor, usually with a specific goal and accomplished in several steps or stages
promote: contribute to the progress or growth of
proof: a formal series of statements showing that if one thing is true something else necessarily follows from it
prosper: make steady progress; be at the high point in one's career or reach a high point in historical significance or importance
protect: shield from danger, injury, destruction, or damage
proud: feeling self-respect or pleasure in something by which you measure your self-worth; or being a reason for pride
provide: give something useful or necessary to
public: not private; open to or concerning the people as a whole
pudding: any of various dishes, sweet or savoury, prepared by boiling or steaming, or from batter
pull: applying force to move something toward or with you
pulp: a soft, moist, shapeless mass or matter
rabbit: any of various burrowing animals of the family Leporidae having long ears and short tails; some domesticated and raised for pets or food
raccoon: a nocturnal omnivore native to North America, typically with a mixture of gray, brown, and black fur, a mask-like marking around the eyes and a striped tail
radar: measuring instrument in which the echo of a pulse of microwave radiation is used to detect and locate distant objects
radio: a communication system based on broadcasting electromagnetic waves
rail: a bar or pair of parallel bars of rolled steel making the railway along which railroad cars or other vehicles can roll
rain: water falling in drops from vapor condensed in the atmosphere
rally: an automobile race run over public roads
ramp: an inclined surface connecting two levels
ranch: farm consisting of a large tract of land along with facilities needed to raise livestock (especially cattle)
random: lacking any definite plan or order or purpose; governed by or depending on chance
range: the limits within which something can be effective
rapid: a part of a river where the current is very fast
rate: a magnitude or frequency relative to a time unit
raven: large black bird with a straight bill and long wedge-shaped tail
ready: completely prepared or in condition for immediate action or use or progress
real: being or occurring in fact or actuality; having verified existence; not illusory
reason: an explanation of the cause of some phenomenon
rebel: take part in a rebellion; renounce a former allegiance
recall: recall knowledge from memory; have a recollection
receive: get something; come into possession of
record: anything (such as a document or a phonograph record or a photograph) providing permanent evidence of or information about past events
reduce: cut down on; make a reduction in
reflect: be bright by reflecting or casting light
reform: form anew; make changes to the something to follow new principles or better follow old principles
region: the extended spatial location of something
regret: to feel sorry about (a thing that has or has not happened), afterthink: to wish that a thing had not happened, that something else had happened instead
regular: having a constant pattern; showing evenness of form or appearance
relax: become less tense, rest, or take one's ease
release: the act of liberating someone or something
relief: the feeling that comes when something burdensome is removed or reduced
remain: stay the same; remain in a certain state
remember: recall knowledge from memory; have a recollection
remind: to cause one to experience a memory (of someone or something); to bring to the notice or consideration (of a person)
remove: to move something from one place to another, especially to take away
renew: reestablish on a new, usually improved, basis or make new or like new
rent: a payment or series of payments made by the lessee to an owner for use of some property, facility, equipment, or service
repair: restore by replacing a part or putting together what is torn or broken
repeat: to do or say again (and again)
replace: substitute a person or thing for (another that is broken or inefficient or lost or no longer working or yielding what is expected)
report: a written document describing the findings of some individual or group
require: naturally to demand (something) as indispensable; to need, to call for as necessary
rescue: recovery or preservation from loss or danger
resemble: appear like; be similar or bear a likeness to
resist: express opposition through action or words
resource: available source of wealth; a new or reserve supply that can be drawn upon when needed
response: an answer or reply, or something in the nature of an answer or reply
result: that which results; the conclusion or end to which any course or condition of things leads, or which is obtained by any process or operation; consequence or effect
retire: stop performing one's work or withdraw from one's position
retreat: (military) withdrawal of troops to a more favorable position to escape the enemy's superior forces or after a defeat
return: the occurrence of a change in direction back in the opposite direction
reunion: a party of former associates who have come together again
reward: payment made in return for a service rendered
rib: any of the 12 pairs of curved arches of bone extending from the spine to or toward the sternum in humans (and similar bones in most vertebrates)
ribbon: any long object resembling a thin line
rice: grains used as food either unpolished or more often polished
ride: sit and travel on the back of animal, usually while controlling its motions
ridge: a long narrow range of hills
rifle: a shoulder firearm with a long barrel and a rifled bore
right: location near or direction toward the right side; i.e. the side to the south when a person or object faces east
rigid: incapable of or resistant to bending
riot: a public act of violence by an unruly mob
ripple: a small wave on the surface of a liquid
risk: a source of danger; a possibility of incurring loss or misfortune
ritual: any customary recurring observance or practice
rival: the contestant you hope to defeat
river: a large natural stream of water (larger than a creek)
road: an open way (generally public) for travel or transportation
roast: cook with dry heat, usually in an oven
robot: a mechanism that can move automatically
robust: sturdy and strong in form, constitution, or construction
rocket: any vehicle self-propelled by a rocket engine
roof: a protective covering that covers or forms the top of a building
room: an area within a building enclosed by walls and floor and ceiling
rose: any of many shrubs of the genus Rosa that bear red, pink, white or yellow flowers
rotate: turn on or around an axis or a center
rough: having or caused by an irregular surface; lacking refinement or finesse
route: an established line of travel or access
royal: of or relating to or indicative of or issued or performed by a king or queen or other monarch
rubber: an elastic material obtained from the latex sap of trees (especially trees of the genera Hevea and Ficus) that can be vulcanized and finished into a variety of products
rug: floor covering consisting of a piece of thick heavy fabric (usually with nap or pile)
rule: a principle or condition that customarily governs behavior
run: move fast by using one's feet, with one foot off the ground at any given time
runway: a strip of level paved surface where planes can take off and land
rural: living in or characteristic of farming or country life
sad: experiencing or showing sorrow or unhappiness
saddle: a seat for the rider of an animal, usually a horse or camel
sadness: the quality of excessive mournfulness and uncheerfulness
safe: strongbox where valuables can be safely kept
sail: a large piece of fabric (usually canvas fabric) by means of which wind is used to propel a boat
salad: food mixtures either arranged on a plate or tossed and served with a moist dressing; usually consisting of or including greens
salmon: any of various large food and game fishes of northern waters; usually migrate from salt to fresh water to spawn
salon: a shop where hairdressers and beauticians work
salt: white crystalline form of especially sodium chloride used to season and preserve food
salute: an act of honor or courteous recognition; a formal military gesture of respect
same: not different or other; not another or others; not different as regards self
sample: a small part of something intended as representative of the whole
sand: a loose material consisting of grains of rock or coral
satisfy: meet the requirements or expectations of; make happy or satisfied
satoshi: last name of the pseudonym of the creator of Bitcoin; a unit of currency equal to 1/100000000 of 1 bitcoin
sauce: a liquid (often thickened) condiment or accompaniment to food
sausage: seasoned minced meat stuffed in elongated casings
save: prevent ruin, destruction, or harm; keep safe, safeguard; spare
scan: make a wide, sweeping search of; in electronics, to reproduce an image
scatter: to cause to separate and go in different directions
scene: the place where some action occurs
scheme: an elaborate and systematic plan of action
science: the collective discipline of study or learning acquired through the scientific method; the sum of knowledge gained from such methods and discipline
scissors: a tool used for cutting thin material, consisting of two crossing blades attached at a pivot point in such a way that the blades slide across each other when the handles are closed
scorpion: a arachnids characterised by two large front pincers and a curved tail with a venomous sting in the end
scout: a person sent out to gain and bring in tidings; especially, one employed in war to gain information about the enemy and ground
scrap: a small fragment of something broken off from the whole
screen: a white or silvered surface where pictures can be projected for viewing
script: a written version of a play or other dramatic composition; used in preparing for a performance
scrub: dense vegetation consisting of stunted trees or bushes
sea: a large body of salt water
search: the activity of looking thoroughly in order to find something or someone
season: one of the natural periods into which the year is divided by the equinoxes and solstices or atmospheric conditions
seat: a space reserved for sitting (as in a theater or on a train or airplane)
second: 1/60 of a minute; the basic unit of time adopted under the Systeme International d'Unites
secret: something that should remain hidden from others (especially information that is not to be passed on); something you only tell one person at a time
section: a part, piece, subdivision of anything
security: the state of being free from danger or injury; (finance) a tradeable financial asset, such as a share of stock
seed: a mature fertilized plant ovule consisting of an embryo and its food source and having a protective coat or testa
seek: try to locate or discover, or try to establish the existence of
segment: one of several parts or pieces that fit with others to constitute a whole object
select: pick out or choose from a number of alternatives
sell: the activity of persuading someone to buy
seminar: a course offered for a small group of advanced students
senior: older; higher in rank; longer in length of tenure or service
sense: any of the manners by which living beings perceive the physical world: for humans sight, smell, hearing, touch, taste
sentence: a string of words satisfying the grammatical rules of a language
series: similar things placed in order or happening one after another
service: an act of being of assistance to someone
session: a meeting for execution of a group's functions
settle: take up residence and become established
setup: the way something is organized or arranged
seven: the cardinal number that is the sum of six and one
shaft: a long rod or pole (especially the handle of an implement or the body of a weapon like a spear or arrow); a vertical passageway through a building (as for an elevator)
shallow: lacking physical depth; having little spatial extension downward or inward from an outer surface or backward or outward from a center
share: give out to others of what one has
shed: an outbuilding with a single story; used for shelter or storage
shell: the material that forms the hard outer covering of many animals
sheriff: the principal law-enforcement officer in a county
shine: the quality of being bright and sending out rays of light
ship: a vessel that carries passengers or freight
shiver: a reflex motion caused by cold or fear or excitement
shock: a sudden, heavy impact; a sudden or violent mental or emotional disturbance
shoe: footwear shaped to fit the foot (below the ankle) with a flexible upper of leather or plastic and a sole and heel of heavier material
shoot: to fire (a weapon that releases a projectile)
shop: a mercantile establishment for the retail sale of goods or services
short: having little or lacking in length or duration
shoulder: the part of the body between the neck and the upper arm
shrimp: small slender-bodied chiefly marine decapod crustaceans with a long tail and single pair of pincers; many species are edible
shrug: raise one's shoulders to indicate indifference or resignation
shuffle: mix so as to make a random order or arrangement
shy: wary and distrustful; disposed to avoid persons or things
sick: affected by an impairment of normal physical or mental function
side: a surface forming part of the outside of an object
siege: the action of an armed force that surrounds a fortified place and isolates it while continuing to attack
sight: the ability to see; the visual faculty
sign: a perceptible indication of something not immediately apparent (as a visible clue that something has happened)
silk: a fabric made from the fine threads produced by certain insect larvae
silver: a soft white precious univalent metallic element having the highest electrical and thermal conductivity of any metal; occurs in argentite and in free form; used in coins and jewelry and tableware and photography
simple: having few parts; not complex or complicated or involved
since: from a specified time in the past
sing: produce tones with the voice; make melodious sounds
siren: a sea nymph (part woman and part bird) supposed to lure sailors to destruction on the rocks where the nymphs lived; an acoustic device producing a loud often wailing sound as a signal or warning
sister: a female person who has the same parents as another person
situate: determine or indicate the place, site, or limits of, as if by an instrument or by a survey
six: the cardinal number that is the sum of five and one
size: the physical magnitude of something (how big it is)
skate: sports equipment that is worn on the feet to enable the wearer to glide along and to be propelled by the alternate actions of the legs
sketch: a rapidly executed freehand drawing that is not intended as a finished work, often consisting of a multitude of overlapping lines
ski: narrow wood or metal or plastic runners used in pairs for gliding over snow
skill: an ability that has been acquired by training
skin: he outer protective layer of the body of an animal or a human
skirt: a garment hanging from the waist; worn mainly by girls and women
skull: the bony skeleton of the head of vertebrates
slab: block consisting of a thick piece of something
slam: a forceful impact that makes a loud noise
sleep: a natural and periodic state of rest during which consciousness of the world is suspended
slender: having little width in proportion to the length or height
slice: a serving that has been cut from a larger portion
slide: move obliquely or sideways, usually in an uncontrolled manner; move smoothly along a surface
slight: small in amount, gentle, or weak; inconsiderable; unimportant; insignificant; not severe
slim: being of delicate or slender build
slogan: a favorite saying of a sect or political group
slot: a small slit (as for inserting a coin or depositing mail); a void waiting to be filled
slow: not moving quickly; taking a comparatively long time
small: not large or big; insignificant; few in number
smile: a facial expression characterized by turning up the corners of the mouth showing pleasure or amusement
smoke: a cloud of fine particles suspended in a gas
smooth: having a surface free from roughness or bumps or ridges or irregularities
snake: limbless scaly elongate reptile; some are venomous
sniff: make a short, audible inhalation, through the nose, as when smelling something
snow: precipitation falling from clouds in the form of ice crystals
soap: a cleansing agent made from the salts of fats from animals of plats
soccer: a football game in which two teams of 11 players try to kick or head a ball into the opponents' goal
social: relating to human society and its members
sock: a knitted or woven covering for the foot; worn inside the shoe; reaches to between the ankle and the knee
soda: a sweet drink containing carbonated water and flavoring
soft: yielding readily to pressure or weight
solar: relating to or derived from the sun or utilizing the energies of the sun
soldier: an enlisted man or woman who serves in an army
solid: (of an object or substance) that can be picked up or held, having a texture, and usually firm, unlike a liquid or a gas
solution: a homogeneous mixture of two or more substances; frequently (but not necessarily) a liquid solution
solve: find the solution to (a problem or question) or understand the meaning of
song: a short musical composition with words
sorry: feeling or expressing regret or sorrow or a sense of loss over something done or undone
sort: a category of things distinguished by some common characteristic or quality
soul: the immaterial part of a person; the actuating cause of an individual life
sound: the particular auditory effect produced by a given cause
soup: liquid food especially of meat or fish or vegetable stock often containing pieces of solid food
source: the place where something begins, where it springs into being
south: the cardinal compass point that is at 180 degrees
space: an empty area (usually bounded in some way between things)
spare: an extra component of a machine or other apparatus
spatial: pertaining to or involving or having the nature of space
special: distinguished by a unique or unusual quality
spell: a verbal formula believed to have magical force
sphere: a three-dimensional closed surface such that every point on the surface is equidistant from the center
spice: any of a variety of pungent aromatic vegetable substances used for flavoring food
spider: predatory arachnid with eight legs, two poison fangs, two feelers, and usually two silk-spinning organs at the back end of the body; they spin silk to make cocoons for eggs or traps for prey
spike: a sort of very large nail; also, a piece of pointed iron set with points upward/outward
spirit: the vital principle or animating force within living things
split: an opening made forcibly as by pulling apart
spoil: become unfit for consumption or use
sponsor: someone who supports or champions something
spoon: a piece of cutlery with a shallow bowl-shaped container and a handle; used to stir or serve or take up food
sport: an active diversion requiring physical exertion and competition
spot: a round or irregular patch on the surface of a thing having a different color, texture etc. and generally round in shape
spray: a fine, gentle, dispersed mist of liquid
spread: to stretch out, open out (a material etc.) so that it more fully covers a given area of space
spy: (military) a secret agent hired by a state to obtain information about its enemies or by a business to obtain industrial secrets from competitors
square: (geometry) a plane rectangle with four equal sides and four right angles; a four-sided regular polygon
squeeze: the act of gripping and pressing firmly
squirrel: a kind of arboreal rodent having a long bushy tail
stable: a farm building for housing horses or other livestock
stadium: a large structure for open-air sports or entertainments
staff: personnel who assist their superior in carrying out an assigned task
stage: a large platform on which people can stand and can be seen by an audience
stairs: a contiguous set of steps connecting two floors
stamp: an indentation, imprint, or mark made by stamping
stand: the position where a thing or person is upright
state: a politically organized body of people under a single government
stay: continuing or remaining in a place or state
steak: a slice of meat cut from the fleshy part of an animal or large fish
steel: an alloy of iron with small amounts of carbon; widely used in construction; mechanical properties can be varied over a wide range
stem: a slender or elongated structure that supports a plant or fungus or a plant part or plant organ
step: the act of changing location by raising the foot and setting it down
stereo: reproducer in which two microphones feed two or more loudspeakers to give a three-dimensional effect to the sound
stick: an implement consisting of a length of wood
sting: to hurt, usually by introducing poison or a sharp point, or both
stock: the capital raised by a corporation through the issue of shares entitling holders to an ownership interest (equity)
stomach: an enlarged and muscular sac-like organ of the alimentary canal; the principal organ of digestion
stone: a lump or mass of hard consolidated mineral matter
stool: a simple seat without a back or arms
story: a piece of fiction that narrates a chain of related events
stove: a kitchen appliance used for cooking food
strategy: an elaborate and systematic plan of action
street: a thoroughfare (usually including sidewalks) that is lined with buildings
strong: having strength or power greater than average or expected
struggle: an energetic attempt to achieve something
student: a learner who is enrolled in an educational institution
stuff: the tangible substance that goes into the makeup of a physical object
stumble: miss a step and fall or nearly fall
style: a way of expressing something (in language or art or music etc.) that is characteristic of a particular person or group of people or period
subject: n
a branch of knowledge
subway: an electric railway operating below the surface of the ground (usually in a city)
success: an event that accomplishes its intended purpose
such: [demonstrative] like this, that, these, those; used to make a comparison with something implied by context
sudden: happening without warning or in a short space of time
suffer: put up with something or somebody unpleasant
sugar: a white crystalline carbohydrate used as a sweetener and preservative
suggest: make a proposal, declare a plan for something
suit: a set of garments (usually including a jacket and trousers or skirt) for outerwear all of the same fabric and color
summer: the warmest season of the year; in the northern hemisphere it extends from the summer solstice to the autumnal equinox
sun: the star that is the source of light and heat for the planets in the solar system
sunny: bright and pleasant; promoting a feeling of cheer
sunset: the time in the evening at which the sun begins to fall below the horizon
super: including more than a specified category
supply: an amount of something available for use
sure: having or feeling no doubt or uncertainty; confident and assured
surface: the outer boundary of an artifact or a material layer constituting or resembling such a boundary
surprise: the astonishment you feel when something totally unexpected happens to you
timber: the wood of trees cut and prepared for use as building material
time: the continuum of experience in which events pass from the future through the present to the past; the only truly limited resource
tip: the extreme end of something; especially something pointed
track: a line or route along which something travels or moves
trade: the commercial exchange (buying and selling on domestic or international markets) of goods and services
traffic: the aggregation of things (pedestrians or vehicles) coming and going in a particular locality during a specified period of time
tragic: very sad; especially involving grief or death or destruction
train: a procession (of wagons or mules or camels) traveling together in single file
transfer: the act of moving something from one location to another
trap: a device in which something (usually an animal) can be caught and penned
trash: worthless material that is to be disposed of
travel: the act of going from one place to another
tray: an open receptacle for holding or displaying or serving articles or food
treat: an occurrence that causes special pleasure or delight
tree: a tall perennial woody plant having a main trunk and branches forming a distinct elevated crown; includes both gymnosperms and angiosperms
trend: a general direction in which something tends to move
tribe: a social division of (usually preliterate) people
trick: a cunning or deceitful action or device
tuna: warm-water fatty fish of the genus Thunnus of the family Scombridae
tunnel: a passageway through or under something, usually underground (especially one for trains or cars)
turkey: large gallinaceous bird with fan-shaped tail; widely domesticated for food
turn: change orientation or direction, also in the abstract sense
turtle: any of various aquatic and land reptiles having a bony shell and flipper-like limbs for swimming
twelve: the cardinal number that is the sum of eleven and one
twenty: the cardinal number that is the sum of nineteen and one
twin: either of two offspring born at the same time from the same pregnancy
twist: to turn one part of something in one direction and another part in the other direction at the same time
two: the cardinal number that is the sum of one and one or a numeral representing this number
type: a subdivision of a particular kind of thing
typical: exhibiting the qualities or characteristics that identify a group or kind or category
uncle: the brother of your father or mother; the husband of your aunt
under: located below or beneath something else
undo: reverse an action or its effect
unfair: not fair; marked by injustice or partiality or deception
unfold: spread out or open from a closed or folded state
unhappy: experiencing or marked by or causing sadness or sorrow or discontent
uniform: clothing of distinctive design worn by members of a particular group as a means of identification
unique: being the only one of its kind; unequaled, unparalleled or unmatched
unit: any division of quantity accepted as a standard of measurement or exchange
unknown: not known; unidentified; not well known
unlock: to undo or open a lock or something locked by, for example, turning a key, or selecting a combination
until: up to the time of (something happening)
unusual: being definitely out of the ordinary and unexpected; slightly odd or even a bit weird
unveil: remove the veil or cover from; make visible
update: bring up to date; supply with recent information; bring to the latest state of technology
upgrade: to improve what was old or outdated
uphold: stand up for; stick up for; of causes, principles, or ideals
upon: being above and in contact with another
upset: an unhappy and worried mental state; the act of disturbing the mind or body
urban: relating to or concerned with a city or densely populated area
urge: an instinctive motive; a strong restless desire
usage: The manner or the amount of using; use; accepted or habitual practice
used: simple past tense and past participle of use
useful: being of use or service; having a useful function
useless: having no beneficial use or incapable of functioning usefully
usual: occurring or encountered or experienced or observed frequently or in accordance with regular practice or procedure
utility: the quality of being of practical use; the service (electric power or water or transportation) provided by a public utility
vacant: void of thought or knowledge; without an occupant or incumbent
vacuum: the absence of matter; an empty area or space
vague: not clearly understood or expressed; not precisely limited, determined, or distinguished
valid: well grounded in logic or truth or having legal force
valley: a long depression in the surface of the land that usually contains a river
valve: a device that controls the flow of a gas or fluid through a pipe
van: a truck with an enclosed cargo space
vanish: get lost, as without warning or explanation; become invisible or unnoticeable
vapor: a visible suspension in the air of particles of some substance
various: a number of distinctly dissimilar or unlike units in a set
vast: unusually great in size or amount or degree or especially extent or scope
vault: a strongroom or compartment (often made of steel) for safekeeping of valuables
vehicle: a conveyance that transports people or objects
velvet: a silky densely piled fabric with a plain back
vendor: someone who promotes or exchanges goods or services for money
venture: a risky or daring undertaking or journey
venue: a theater, auditorium, arena, or other area designated for sporting or entertainment events
